fields.description: To track Windows Integration Tool related tasks
fields.summary: Windows Integration tool update

comments.body:
The integration tool should be updated to include most of the features in the EC2Config tool from AWS:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/UsingConfig_WinAMI.html

EC2Config runs initial startup tasks when the instance is first started and then disables them. To run these tasks again, you must explicitly enable them prior to shutting down the instance, or by running Sysprep manually. These tasks are as follows:

* Set the computer name (to match the private DNS name).

* Set a random, encrypted password for the Administrator account.

* Generate and install the host certificate used for Remote Desktop Connection.

* Dynamically extend the operating system partition.

* Execute the specified User Data (and CloudInit, if it's installed).

EC2Config performs the following tasks every time the instance starts:

* Check for activation status and activate Windows as necessary.

* Configure the Key Management Server (KMS) and activate Windows.

* Format and mount any EBS volumes and instance store volumes, and map volume names to drive letters.

* Synchronize the instance clock with a time server.

* Write event log entries to the console to help with troubleshooting.

* Write to the console that Windows is ready.

* Display wallpaper information to the desktop background.

* Add a custom route to the primary network adapter to enable the following IP addresses when multiple NICs are attached: 169.254.169.250, 169.254.169.251, and 169.254.169.254. These addresses are used by Windows Activation and when you access instance metadata. (optional - not sure if its needed for on-premise clouds)

While the instance is running, you can request that EC2Config perform the following task on demand:

* Run Sysprep and shut down the instance so that you can create an AMI from it.

*A Bit of Research*

For processing the user-data and instance meta-data of an instance, we could do the following:

* Install [cURL for Windows|http://curl.haxx.se/download.html] on the image as part of the Windows Integration tool bootstrapping, and then create a task to poll 169.254.169.254 on start up.

or 

* Use [BITS|http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa362819(v=vs.85).aspx] via [Windows Powershell script|http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ee663885(v=vs.85).aspx] or add it to the Windows Integration tool with [C++/C#|http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/magazine/cc188766.aspx]

_*User-Data Powershell Scripts*_

Here is an article that discusses the importance of setting the [execution policy for Powershell scripts|http://windowsitpro.com/powershell/ps-101-checking-and-setting-powershell-execution-policy].  Just something to keep in mind when implementing this feature.  We may want to tie it to [account admins being able to upload and manage server certificates in IAM|http://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/InstallCert.html]?  Until then, maybe just use _Unrestricted_ execution policy?  Thoughts?

We should talk to AWS to see what the license is on the EC2Config tool and whether they would be willing to open source it.

cc [~gregdek] on that

*Update*

Found the current project on github:

https://github.com/bwight/CloudInit.NET

Could be something to look at and see if we could ingress it into the Windows Integration Tool.

Thanks [~dshekhawat], [~hspencer] - Great feedback and background info on this topic. Currently discussing with [~spark] on prioritizing these in the 3.4 timeframe (or earlier, if we can get help on QA from CS / community). Thanks.
https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/PRD-40  << I think this is not related to windows tools.
There's a cloud property for limit on image size?
[~spark] - Can you provide more info on the property? (this came up during a conversation Sang-Min and I were having)
